Award.AwardTitle: Bats Jamming Bats: A Novel Form of Intraspecific Competition
Award.AbstractNarration:
Predator/prey interactions represent life and death struggles, especially for the prey. Moths have developed a wide variety of behaviors to avoid being captured as they fly at night by bats. The researchers study a system in which species of tiger moths have developed the ability to "jam" the sonar, or echolocation, of bats. The moths produce high-frequency sounds that interfere with the bat's ability to hear echoes returning from the moth, making them very difficult to catch. During the first-ever field study of sonar-jamming, the experimenters discovered a sound that Mexican free-tailed bats make while competing for insects against other Mexican free-tailed bats. The bat's call has many similarities with the moth's jamming signal. Using high speed video and high frequency microphone arrays in the field and lab, the experimenters will determine whether bats jam one another deliberately while competing for food. If this is so (and preliminary evidence suggests that it is), then this would be the first discovery that any echolocating animal actively jams individuals of the same species for their benefit. This work will allow us to compare how jamming works in moths and bats, and how this compares to jamming in modern human warfare. This research may have implications for developing acoustic bat deterrents and in understanding the biology of animals that provide billions of dollars in insect pest control each year.

This research will educate graduate students, undergraduates, and grade-school children. The most exciting educational aspect of this proposal is a partnership with SciWorks in Forsyth Co., NC. SciWorks is a Science Center and Environmental Park visited by over 40,000 K through 12 students per year (many of whom are minorities and/or economically disadvantaged). The Conner laboratory will provide a variety of presentations and assist in the development of interactive exhibits for SciWorks based on the research described in this proposal.

POR.DRECONTENT:
If you watch a bat zipping after insects around a streetlight, it appears to be quiet, but it is anything but that. Bats make some of the loudest sounds in nature—so loud that it would hurt your ears if you could hear such high frequencies. By listening to faint echoes that return within milliseconds, the bat can “see” the world around it. These sounds are one of the bat’s greatest assets, but they are also a liability. Unlike us, other animals, including many insects and other bats, can hear bat calls from some distance. When a moth hears a bat, it flees desperately. If that early strategy fails, it tries to out-maneuver the bat. We’ve also discovered that some moths make specialized high-frequency clicks that jam the bat’s echolocation. When studying these jamming signals in the field, we discovered a highly-unusual sound that the bats were making. This bat sound, which we later termed the sinFM, rises and falls in pitch some 150 times per second and it matches the frequencies used by other bats. What stood out to us about this sound was that we only recorded it when another bat was making its specialized “feeding buzz” calls used for capturing prey. Could the bats be jamming one another, just like the moths that we studied? To answer this question, we used specialized infrared cameras and microphones that would allow us to see and hear what the bats were doing. A major accomplishment of this grant was developing technology to study these elusive creatures, something that few people had done previously. Now, we can capture details of bats hunting insects and interacting with each other that have long been missed in the darkness. What we found out was incredible. Bats were in fact jamming each other—often dueling back and forth five, six or seven times until one gave up to look for food elsewhere. We confirmed this finding by playing back the sinFM calls and other sounds to wild bats that we lured in to attacking a moth that we had suspended in the air with a fine fishing line. Just as we expected, the bats had no problem catching the moths in silence, or when we played sounds outside the frequency range of their echolocation. But when we played sinFM calls, the bats missed the moths again and again. We showed for the first time that animals use specialized jamming signals against competitors. This was an exciting discovery of what animals are capable of doing in nature. It could also reveal insights into how we process sounds, and how that process breaks down. Bats are mammals, just like us. And also like us, their brains are very good at turning complex sounds into meaningful information. Because sinFM calls evolved specifically to break down the process of hearing, they could hold the key to understanding how our brains fail to separate competing signals.

 

This research also allowed us to collaborate with SciWorks Science Center and Environmental Park in developing educational exhibits that are visited by over 40,000 K through 12 students per year. Many of these students come from disadvantaged backgrounds, and might not otherwise get these kinds of opportunities to learn about science. The exhibits include a 100-foot echo tube that allows students to vocalize and hear their echoes to better understand how echolocation works. We also designed and implemented a mural in SciWorks that describes the folklore, natural history, behavior, and diversity of bats in South America (a place of particularly-high bat diversity). We’ve also had lots of fun interacting with the students during regular presentations on the fascinating lives of bats.
